case_name: Patna Electric Supply Co., Ltd. v. Patna Electric Supply Workers Union

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 227 of 1958 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 227 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1956,

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and order dated January 31, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeals Nos. Cal. 36 and 38 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 227 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeals Nos. Cal. 36 and 38 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 23, 1959 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959 April 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal by special leave arises out of an industrial dispute between the

facts.text: Appellant is Patna Electric Supply Co., Ltd., a public company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act with registered office at Patna.

anchor.surface_text: the Patna Electric Supply Co., Ltd.,  hereafter called the appellant  and its workmen represented by the Patna Electric Supply Workers Union  hereafter called the respondent . The appellant is a public companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act and has its registered office at Patna.

facts.text: Appellant is engaged solely in public utility service of supply of electricity and is a licensee under the Electric Supply Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It is an industrial establishment engaged solely in public utility service, namely,, the supply of electricity for the requirements of the public and is a licensee under the provisions of the Electric Supply Act, 1948  54 of 1948 .

facts.text: On March 29, 1952, Government of Bihar referred twelve items of dispute to Industrial Tribunal consisting of Mr. H. K. Chaudhuri.

anchor.surface_text: On March 29, 1952, the Government of Bihar, by a numberification issued under s. 7 read with s. 10 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  14 of 1947   hereafter called the Act  referred twelve items of dispute for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal companysisting of Mr. H. K. Chaudhuri as the sole member.

facts.text: Dispute relates to housing facilities to the workmen and principle of allotment of quarters.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the said items the present appeal is companycerned with only one and it relates to the housing facilities to the workmen and principle of allotment of quarters to them .

facts.text: Respondent demanded appellant provide houses and construct quarters immediately according to Bihar Government scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had put forward a demand that the appellant should provide houses to its employees and should undertake the companystruction of quarters immediately in that belie.

facts.text: Appellant denied liability to provide housing for employees.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied its liability to make any housing provision for its employees and that gave rise to the industrial dispute.

facts.text: Appellant claimed housing is primary responsibility of State, financially impossible, and restricted by Electricity Supply Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant urged before the tribunal that the housing facilities and allotment of quarters to workmen was the primary responsibility of the State and number of the employer and it alleged that in any event it was financially number possible for the appellant to undertake the task.

facts.text: On March 9, 1953, Industrial Tribunal upheld respondent's claim and directed construction of at least 15 quarters within one year from publication.

anchor.surface_text: On March 9, 1953, the tribunal upheld the respondents claim and by its award it directed the appellant to start companystruction of at least 15 quarters according to the specifications laid down in the Government scheme within one year from the date of the publication of the award.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal dismissed appellant's appeal on January 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This part of the award was challenged by the appellant before the Labour Appellate Tribunal but the appellate tribunal was number impressed by the appellants pleas and so it dismissed the appeal on January 31, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court on September 17, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for, and obtained, special leave from this Court on September 17, 1956 .

facts.text: Appellant provided free quarters to 17 out of 183 employees in Power Station, 146 out of 329 in Mains Department, 1 out of 58 in General Department; one employee in Mains gets house allowance of 12.5%.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that 17 employees out of 183 in the Power Station, 146 out of 329 in the Mains Department, and 1 out of 58 in the General, Department have been provided by the appellant with free quarters, whereas one employee in the Mains Department is granted house allowance at 12 1/2 in lieu of a house.

facts.text: Bihar Government set up Bihar Labour Enquiry Committee in March 1938 under Dr. Rajendra Prasad; report submitted April 1940.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in March 1938 the Government of Bihar had set up a Committee known as the Bihar Labour Enquiry Committee under the Chairmanship of Dr. Rajendra Prasad for the purpose of enquiring into the companyditions of industrial labour in the State and for making such recommendations as might appear practicable with the object of improving the level of wages and companyditions of work of industrial workers.

facts.text: Industrial Housing Sub-Committee submitted report on December 16, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the Bihar Government appointed the Industrial Housing Sub-Committee on the recommendation of the Bihar Central  Standing  Labour Advisory Board and this Sub- Committee submitted its report on December 16, 1948, recommending the setting up of an industrial housing board for formulating certain schemes for housing industrial workers.

facts.text: Bihar Central Standing Labour Advisory Board considered matter on February 11, 1950, and asked Sub-Committee to re-examine.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then companysidered by the Bihar Central  Standing  Labour Advisory Board on February 11, 1950, and the Board asked the Industrial Housing Sub- Committee to re-examine the question further and make specific recommendations.

facts.text: Sub-Committee made final recommendations on August 17, 1950; adopted by Board in September 1950 with modifications; sanctioned by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the Sub. Committee reconsidered the matter and made its final recommendations on August 17, 1950. These recommendations were companysidered by the Bihar Central  Standing  Labour Advisory Board in September 1950 and they were adopted by it with slight modifications. This scheme was finally sanctioned by the State Government.

facts.text: Scheme places responsibility for housing on employers, provides state loan of 50% capital at 3% interest, repayable in 25 annual instalments.

anchor.surface_text: Under this scheme the responsibility for housing industrial labour is placed on the shoulders of the employers. ... It appears that under para. 4 of the scheme the State Government may give loan to the employer. to the extent of 50 of the capital required for industrial housing and that the loan would carry interest at 3 per annum. The remaining 50 of the capital is to be provided for by the employer.

facts.text: No representative of appellant was member of Committee when scheme adopted in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: No partner of the appellant was a member of the Committee and Mr. Chandra the appellants Labour Adviser was number its member in 1950 but became one in 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds scheme is recommendatory, no statutory force, does not bind appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the scheme in question can justify the direction issued by the, award under appeal. It is clear that though the original Bihar Labour Enquiry Committee had recommended ... the scheme in question on which the respondent relies has numberstatutory force.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside the award.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeal succeeds and the award under appeal is set aside.

facts.text: Industrial tribunals consistently hold providing housing is primary responsibility of State.

anchor.surface_text: Industrial tribunals have companysistently taken the view that housing accommodation of industrial labour is the primary responsibility of the State

facts.text: No legislation imposing statutory housing obligation on employers in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the State Legislature has passed numberlegislation imposing statutory obligation on the employer to provide for housing on an adequate scale to his employees.

issues.text: whether the direction issued by the award calling upon the appellant to start the construction of at least 15 quarters is justified or not

anchor.surface_text: That is how this appeal has come to this Court, and the only question which it raises for our decision is whether the direction issued by the award calling upon the appellant to start the construction of at least 15 quarters is justified or not.

issues.text: whether the scheme sanctioned by the Bihar Government on the recommendation of the Industrial Housing Sub-Committee, though recommendatory in character, imposes a moral obligation on the employer to provide housing for his employees, and in industrial adjudication this moral obligation can be enforced against it

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the scheme in question can justify the direction issued by the, award under appeal. It is clear that though the original Bihar Labour Enquiry Committee had recommended to the State Government that housing on an adequate scale should be made a statutory obligation of the employer

holdings.text: The scheme in question cannot justify the direction issued by the award under appeal as it has no statutory force.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the scheme in question can justify the direction issued by the, award under appeal. It is clear that though the original Bihar Labour Enquiry Committee had recommended

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme is recommendatory, approved recommendations of advisory board; State only offers optional financial assistance; no legislation imposes obligation; appellant had no consent or representation.

holdings.text: The scheme does not bind the appellant as it had no representation on the committee when adopted.

anchor.surface_text: No partner of the appellant was a member of the Committee and Mr. Chandra the appellants Labour Adviser was number its member in 1950 but became one in 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No partner or representative on committee in 1950; Mr. Chandra joined later and represents multiple companies; mere nomination of some employers does not bind all.

holdings.text: Tribunals cannot direct employers to construct quarters by forcing government to advance loans under the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that tribunals cannot call upon the Government to advance a loan to the employers whenever they pass awards calling upon the employers to start the companystruction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme merely recommendatory; tribunals lack jurisdiction to compel state financial aid; non-compliance risks penalties despite state delays.

holdings.text: The scheme cannot introduce a term of employment regarding housing facilities.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the scheme in question which is the sole basis for the award cannot have the effect of introducing a term of employment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme vague and recommendatory; use of 'mainly' shows non-binding nature; cannot be enforced as stands.

holdings.text: Housing accommodation of industrial labour is the primary responsibility of the State.

holdings.text: In present economic conditions, it is inexpedient to impose housing obligation on employers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wages and dearness allowance account for housing; tribunals consistently refuse such claims; would burden industry, affect national economy.

holdings.text: Industrial adjudication may impose new obligations on employers in appropriate cases for social justice and industrial peace.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that in appropriate cases industrial adjudication may impose new obligations on the employer in the interest of social justice and with the object

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recognized since Federal Court decisions; unlike commercial arbitration, can create/modify rights for peace; cited precedents like Western India Automobile, Bharat Bank.

holdings.text: Apart from the scheme, the award cannot be justified on general grounds under present conditions.

anchor.surface_text: But assuming that the tribunal had jurisdiction to entertain the dispute, the question still remains whether, apart from the agreement on which the tribunals

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if jurisdiction exists, housing not appropriate now; state primary responsibility; economic conditions preclude; tribunals consistently refuse.

holdings.text: The award under appeal cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the award under appeal cannot be sustained on the basis of the scheme sanctioned by the Bihar Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme lacks binding force; no jurisdiction/applicability for housing imposition currently.

holdings.text: The appeal succeeds and the award under appeal is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The result is the appeal succeeds and the award under appeal is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: On merits, direction unjustified; scheme not binding, housing state responsibility, economic inexpediency.

precedents.citation: Western India Automobile Association v. The Industrial Tribunal, Bombay A.I.R. 1949 F.C. III, 120.

anchor.surface_text: Federal Court in Western India Automobile Association v. The Industrial Tribunal, Bombay  2 . In that case the employer had challenged the jurisdiction of the industrial tribunal to direct the reinstatement of his employees and it was urged that such a direction was

precedents.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: industrial adjudication does not mean adjudication according to the strict law of master and servant; tribunal not fettered by ordinary law limitations
precedents.cited_holding: The award of the tribunal may contain provisions for the settlement of a dispute which no Court could order if it was bound by ordinary law, but the tribunal is not fettered in any way by these limitations.

precedents.citation: The Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. The Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi 1950 S.C.R 459, 513.

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been more emphatically expressed by Mukherjea, J., in The Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. The Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi  1 ,. In settling the disputes between the employers and the workmen , observed the learned Judge,

precedents.case_name: Bharat Bank Ltd. v. Employees of Bharat Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: industrial tribunal's function is not confined to administration of justice in accordance with law; it can confer new rights and obligations for industrial peace
precedents.cited_holding: It can create new rights and obligations between them which it considers essential for keeping industrial peace.

precedents.citation: Rohtas Industries Ltd. v. Brijnandan Pandey 1956 S.C.R. 800, 810.

anchor.surface_text: In Rohtas Industries Ltd. v. Brijnandan Pandey Mr. Justice S. Das has expressed the same conclusion when he observed that a court of law proceeds on the footing that no power exists in the courts to make contracts for people

precedents.case_name: Rohtas Industries Ltd. v. Brijnandan Pandey
precedents.cited_proposition: Industrial Tribunal is not fettered like courts and may create new obligations or modify contracts in interests of industrial peace
precedents.cited_holding: An Industrial Tribunal is not so fettered and may create new obligations or modify contracts in the interests of industrial peace, to protect legitimate trade union activities and to prevent unfair practice or victimisation.

precedents.citation: Eastern Plywood Manufacturing Co., Ltd., And Their Workers 1949 L.L.J. 291.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, refer to a few typical decisions of the Industrial Tribunals on this point. In Eastern Plywood Manufacturing Co., Ltd., And Their Workers  1  the Industrial Tribunal rejected the workmens claim for housing accommodation

precedents.case_name: Eastern Plywood Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Their Workers
precedents.cited_proposition: obligation for housing labour in urban area not on employer; house rent considered in basic pay and DA

precedents.citation: Mahomad Rai Akbarali Khan v. The Associated Cement Companies Ltd. 1953 L.A.C. 677.

precedents.case_name: Mahomad Rai Akbarali Khan v. Associated Cement Companies Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: providing housing not function of management generally; readjust DA to account for house rent instead of separate allowance or quarters

anchor.surface_text: In Samastipur Central Sugar Co., Ltd., And Their Workmen  1  the Labour Appellate Tribunal had occasion to consider this question once again. In dealing with the merits of the problem, it accepted the decision of the Appellate Tribunal

precedents.case_name: Samastipur Central Sugar Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: house rent taken into account in consolidated basic wage and DA

precedents.citation: Messrs. National Carbon Co. India Ltd. v. National Carbon Co., Mazdoor Union, Calcutta 1956 L.A.C. 660.

anchor.surface_text: The same view was taken by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Messrs. National Carbon Co.  India  Ltd. v. National Carbon Co., Mazdoor Union, Calcutta  3 . In that case the tribunal had directed the employer to pay his workmen house rent allowance
